  • ocsigen/jsofocaml#4cd7df4 complete removal of wasmofocaml backend (~32K lines), transforming project to pure JavaScript compilation
  • ocaml/dune#10892 improved dune file formatting to fill lines instead of vertical layout for version 3.17+ by Nicolás Ojeda Bär
  • ocaml/dune#11025 lazy dependency closure computation in package management for better performance
  • ocaml/ocamlfind#80 fixed compiler flag autodetection for OCaml 5.2 by Stephen Dolan
  • ocaml/odoc#1218 enhanced developer workflow with gitignore entries for odoc driver output directories

    • Overview

  • Release milestone with ocaml/opam#2.3.0-beta1 delivering comprehensive bug fixes and platform improvements
  • Architecture transformation in ocsigen/jsofocaml removing WASM backend (~32K lines) to focus on JavaScript compilation
  • Development workflow improvements across ocaml/dune, ocaml/odoc, and ocaml/ocamlfind with formatting, navigation, and OCaml 5.x compatibility fixes
  • Planning phase for ocaml/odoc 3.0 infrastructure with multiple issues for package integration and driver enhancements
  • Developer tooling focus in ocaml/merlin with OCaml 5.3 compatibility and enhanced navigation capabilities

    • Activity

  • ocaml/opam release coordination by Kate with platform binary preparation and R. Boujbel handling install script updates for #6238
  • ocaml/dune package management enhancements including bug fixes for watch mode crashes #10960 and dependency filtering improvements #11021
  • ocsigen/jsofocaml complete documentation rewrite and runtime system modernization following backend removal
  • ocaml/ocamlfind OCaml 5.x compatibility delivered through multiple merged PRs for thread handling #76 and build system cleanup #75
  • ocaml/odoc three major PRs opened including index pages improvement #1221, sidebar overhaul #1220, and frontmatter syntax #1210
  • ocaml/merlin file navigation improvements by Ulysse for OCaml 5.3 source information handling #1857

    • Notable Discussions

  • PKGCONFIGPATH handling issue on macOS reported by Dmitriy Kovalenko in ocaml/dune#10805 where dune-configurator ignores custom paths
  • Coq extraction error identified by Jean-Marie Madiot in ocaml/dune#11014 with poor error messaging when mixing stanzas
  • Syntax design debate in ocaml/odoc#1210 between sexp-based frontmatter and existing @-tags approach, with Daniel Bünzli advocating for consistency
  • Index page patterns discussed in ocaml/odoc#1221 regarding automatically generated vs handmade pages for better navigation
  • Domhtml modernization request by Jérôme Vouillon in ocsigen/jsof_ocaml#1719 for updating mouse event properties and removing IE compatibility

    • Emerging Trends

  • Release stabilization focus with extensive platform testing in ocaml/opam covering multiple architectures including new RISC-V support
  • Architecture simplification trend in ocsigen/jsofocaml moving from dual JS/WASM targets to single JavaScript focus
  • Enhanced developer experience priority across tools with navigation improvements in ocaml/merlin, formatting enhancements in ocaml/dune, and comprehensive documentation redesign in ocaml/odoc
  • OCaml version compatibility efforts ensuring tooling works with OCaml 5.x across ocaml/ocamlfind and ocaml/merlin
  • Infrastructure modernization with CI/CD enhancements in ocaml/opam and comprehensive planning for ocaml/odoc 3.0 architecture

    • OxCaml

    Major oxcaml compiler restructuring and merlin enhancements with OCaml 5.2.0minus-1 integration

    New Features

  • Added get_header_masked function in oxcaml/oxcaml cmm_helpers module for clearing reserved bits from block headers (d063df2969bf)
  • Implemented continuation lifting optimization in Flambda2 compiler in oxcaml/oxcaml (d835ee41806639)
  • Integrated 5.2 multicore markdelay functionality for improved garbage collection in oxcaml/oxcaml (f937ddd5f5970)
  • Enhanced locate command in oxcaml/merlin with new -context flag allowing explicit namespace specification via values like expr, module_path, type, constructor, label, etc. (oxcaml/merlin#91)
  • New magic numbers update script (update-magic-numbers.sh) in oxcaml/merlin for automated OCaml version compatibility maintenance (oxcaml/merlin#108)
  • Fixed unsoundness issue in oxcaml/oxcaml where locks beyond open statements were incorrectly ignored (2a894ebf4b84f)
  • Improved ghost location handling in oxcaml/merlin occurrences query by switching from ghost location filtering to Location.none filtering (oxcaml/merlin#110)

    • Overview

  • Major infrastructure overhaul in oxcaml/oxcaml with complete backend directory restructuring and advanced compiler optimizations including continuation lifting and multicore garbage collection improvements
  • Development tooling advancement in oxcaml/merlin with enhanced locate functionality, OCaml 5.2.0minus-1 integration, and automated maintenance scripts
  • Cross-project coordination evident between oxcaml/merlin and ocaml-flambda/flambda-backend for synchronized changes and upstream integration planning
  • Active development limited to 2 of 5 repositories during this period, with oxcaml/opam-repository, oxcaml/jsofocaml, and janestreet/opam-repository showing no activity

    • Activity

  • Repository restructuring completed in oxcaml/oxcaml by moving entire backend/ directory structure to asmcomp/ location, affecting hundreds of files including compiler internals and architecture-specific code
  • Runtime compatibility addressed in oxcaml/oxcaml with Leo White reporting OCAMLRUNPARAM=v=4096 flag overloading issue (oxcaml/oxcaml#3158)
  • OCaml 5.2.0minus-1 integration delivered in oxcaml/merlin by Liam Stevenson bringing latest flambda backend changes (oxcaml/merlin#106)
  • Development workflow improvements in oxcaml/merlin with code cleanup removing unused magic numbers (oxcaml/merlin#107) and new automated tooling (oxcaml/merlin#108)
  • Bug fix implementation in oxcaml/merlin for EXCLUDEQUERYDIR directive handling in cmt/cms files (oxcaml/merlin#104)
  • Type system enhancements completed in oxcaml/oxcaml with layouts documentation (oxcaml/oxcaml#3144) and unboxed vector types fixes (oxcaml/oxcaml#3138)

    • Emerging Trends

  • Compiler architecture consolidation with major directory restructuring in oxcaml/oxcaml moving backend functionality into asmcomp for better organization and maintenance
  • Development automation emphasis with creation of tooling in oxcaml/merlin for automated magic numbers maintenance, reducing manual overhead for OCaml version updates
  • Cross-repository coordination maturity evident through systematic synchronization between oxcaml/merlin and ocaml-flambda/flambda-backend projects for feature development and integration
  • Runtime system refinement addressing compatibility issues in oxcaml/oxcaml between custom extensions and upstream OCaml changes
  • User experience improvements through enhanced locate command functionality in oxcaml/merlin providing more precise control over identifier resolution

    • OCaml Core

    Five PRs merged in ocaml/ocaml including new Thread.set_current_thread_name API and compiler improvements

    New Features

  • New Thread.setcurrentthread_name function allows setting thread names from within thread functions, available on most systems that support the functionality (ocaml/ocaml#13504)
  • Documentation improvements for -safe-string option clarification in Bytes module interface explaining immutability invariant protection (ocaml/ocaml@1e5d73946f)
  • GC verbose flag documentation reformatted with cleaner hexadecimal notation (0x001 instead of 0x0001) in Gc.control interface (ocaml/ocaml@1e5d73946f)
  • String.to_seq documentation enhanced to clarify behavior in "unsafe-string" mode where modifications during iteration are reflected in sequence (ocaml/ocaml@1e5d73946f)

    • Overview

  • ocaml/ocaml delivered five merged PRs including a new threading API, runtime events improvements, and documentation clarifications
  • ocaml/RFCs had no activity during this period

    • Activity

  • Runtime events enhancement by Thomas Leonard with addition of Runtime_events.EV_EMPTY_MINOR event for better garbage collection monitoring (ocaml/ocaml#13407)
  • Memory documentation improvement by @andyhhp adding discussion of CAMLnoreturn attribute usage in memory.h header (ocaml/ocaml#13561)
  • Local module type substitution fix by Florian Angeletti addressing issue ocaml/ocaml#13388 where local substitution could fail (ocaml/ocaml#13540)
  • Manual clarification by Olivier Nicole disambiguating the -with-runtime option documentation (ocaml/ocaml#12912)
  • Testsuite cleanup by @hhugo removing unnecessary string-bytes conversions for better jsofocaml compatibility (ocaml/ocaml#13550)
  • Ongoing modular explicits development with Samuel Vivien continuing work on ocaml/ocaml#13275, a feature for module-parametrized functions enabling convenient abstraction over higher-kinded types

    • Multicore

    Eio gained public fork action headers and Windows compatibility while Picos delivered performance optimizations and hash table enhancements

    New Features

  • Public header exposure for fork_action.h in ocaml-multicore/eio enabling external libraries to provide new fork actions by Patrick Ferris (ocaml-multicore/eio#769)
  • Windows symlink test compatibility check using Unix.has_symlink() to skip symlink tests on systems without support in ocaml-multicore/eio by Onah_Anthony (ocaml-multicore/eio#771)
  • Hash table consensus operations added comprehensive set of atomic operations including try_set, try_compare_and_set, set_exn, try_compare_and_remove in ocaml-multicore/picos designed for building consensus protocols over arbitrary numbers of processes (ocaml-multicore/picos#317)
  • Trigger documentation improvements with enhanced explanations of scheduler interface and added usage notes for Trigger.from_action in ocaml-multicore/picos (ocaml-multicore/picos#318)

    • Overview

  • Active development focused on two repositories: ocaml-multicore/eio improving Windows compatibility and external library integration, and ocaml-multicore/picos delivering performance optimizations
  • Cross-platform support prioritized with Windows symlink compatibility fixes (ocaml-multicore/eio#771) and ongoing Windows test suite enablement work (ocaml-multicore/eio#761)
  • External integration enhanced through public header exposure enabling external libraries to extend fork actions (ocaml-multicore/eio#769)
  • Performance focus with multiple optimization PRs merged in ocaml-multicore/picos covering computation waiting, stack usage reduction, and inlining improvements
  • Seven repositories remained inactive during this week: ocaml-multicore/domainslib, ocaml-multicore/ocaml-uring, ocaml-multicore/meio, ocaml-multicore/saturn, ocaml-multicore/eio-trace, ocaml-multicore/kcas, ocaml-multicore/ocaml-iomux

    • Activity

  • Type system improvements in ocaml-multicore/eio with Process.pipe type relaxation work by Isaac Arogbonlo (ocaml-multicore/eio#767, ocaml-multicore/eio#770) to improve API compatibility with monomorphic types
  • Windows compatibility initiatives including ongoing Windows test suite enablement efforts (ocaml-multicore/eio#761) and additional Windows symlink test improvements (ocaml-multicore/eio#766, ocaml-multicore/eio#768)
  • Performance optimization series in ocaml-multicore/picos by Vesa Karvonen including fast path tweaks for computation waiting/peeking (ocaml-multicore/picos#310), stack usage reduction (ocaml-multicore/picos#311, ocaml-multicore/picos#312), and inlining improvements (ocaml-multicore/picos#309)
  • External dependency integration with removal of internal Countdown implementation in favor of using version from multicore-bench library in ocaml-multicore/picos (ocaml-multicore/picos#316)

    • Notable Discussions

  • Documentation feedback exchange in ocaml-multicore/picos between Carine Morel and Vesa Karvonen covering Trigger module documentation clarity, particularly around grammatical usage of "and" vs "or" connectors, alert handler formatting, and explanation of engineering terminology (ocaml-multicore/picos#39)

    • Emerging Trends

  • Windows platform support receiving increased attention across the group with multiple contributors working on test compatibility in ocaml-multicore/eio (ocaml-multicore/eio#761, ocaml-multicore/eio#766, ocaml-multicore/eio#768, ocaml-multicore/eio#771, ocaml-multicore/eio#738)
  • External library integration focus with both ocaml-multicore/eio public header exposure (ocaml-multicore/eio#769) and type system compatibility improvements (ocaml-multicore/eio#750, ocaml-multicore/eio#767, ocaml-multicore/eio#770)
  • Performance optimization emphasis with systematic improvements in ocaml-multicore/picos covering multiple aspects of runtime efficiency (ocaml-multicore/picos#309, ocaml-multicore/picos#310, ocaml-multicore/picos#311, ocaml-multicore/picos#312)
  • Documentation quality improvements prioritized with enhanced clarity and user experience focus in ocaml-multicore/picos (ocaml-multicore/picos#313, ocaml-multicore/picos#315, ocaml-multicore/picos#318, ocaml-multicore/picos#39)
entry.summary: Major opam 2.3.0-beta1 release coordinated across ecosystem with extensive package additions and tooling improvements
